quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we dig into why Maya is obsessed with dogfooding and why she encourages everyone on her team to create their own podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete product-leadership practice (dogfooding) and a specific team behavior (everyone creates a podcast) that practitioners can apply.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, a bunch of really fun early Anchor stories, including how interns uploaded podcasts to Apple and Spotify manually before they could automate that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A vivid example of scrappy execution—manual ops to validate and scale before investing in automation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think we are now officially over a third of global market share of podcast listening, which is pretty insane.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A concrete market-share data point that signals Spotify’s scale and the competitive context for product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Yeah, I think at this point it's more than 75% of all new shows on Spotify are hosted with Spotify for podcasters, which used to be Anchor.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A specific adoption metric showing the dominance of Spotify’s creator/hosting funnel and Anchor’s impact.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When we were acquired by Spotify, I think Anchor had already gotten to 40% of all new podcasts or something crazy.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A pre-acquisition traction benchmark that illustrates how far Anchor scaled before being integrated into a larger org.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding through making multiple podcasts
quotes.text: But when I got into audio and trying to help audio creators, the first thing I did was make my own podcast because I was like, I know nothing about production or what it feels to even be a creator in that way.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A clear dogfooding methodology: become the user/creator yourself to uncover realities you can’t learn secondhand.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding through making multiple podcasts
quotes.text: If you're trying to figure out what to make a show about, it's what can you talk about for?
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Actionable topic-selection heuristic for creators: choose a subject you can sustain conversationally over time.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding through making multiple podcasts
quotes.text: I spent a ton of time editing it. I spent a ton of time on SEO and marketing it, and it got to the point, I think at its peak I was getting 5,000 listeners in a episode, which now seems small for a podcast, I know.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Concrete example tying specific growth levers (editing, SEO, marketing) to a measurable outcome (5,000 listeners/episode).

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding through making multiple podcasts
quotes.text: I wanted to get the other end of the spectrum where something we were really focused on with Anchor at the time was first time creators really growing the pie of podcasters and specifically we had this theory that podcast creation of the future would be mobile first and we had this really high-powered mobile app, and so I was like, I'm going to make a podcast that's fully mobile, not highly edited, not worry about making something that sounds like a traditional podcast.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A product-testing approach: validate a strategic thesis (mobile-first creation) by building in the extreme constraints of the target workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Dogfooding through making multiple podcasts
quotes.text: And that I think is one of the many things I've learned from dogfooding, a podcast creation app is that community piece is so important. If you don't know if anyone's listening, if you don't know what they like about it, if you don't know if they're coming back, it's so hard to keep investing the time.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Highlights a retention driver practitioners can design for: feedback and community signals reduce creator uncertainty and sustain effort.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing dogfooding across the product team
quotes.text: I really don't think that you can build the right things.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A blunt dogfooding principle: building creator tools requires firsthand creator experience, not just user interviews and data.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing dogfooding across the product team
quotes.text: If you're just looking at a list of feature requests, you're not necessarily going to prioritize it in the same way as if you deeply feel those problems.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Highlights why embodied user pain changes prioritization more than abstract inputs like requests and dashboards.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing dogfooding across the product team
quotes.text: So we really elevate the people on our team who have their own podcasts, we help them tell their stories internally. Whenever we do an offsite or any team activity, we'll always incorporate podcast creation or some way of making sure everyone on the team is using the tools.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Concrete operational tactics for making dogfooding habitual: recognition, storytelling, and structured creation moments.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing dogfooding across the product team
quotes.text:
The other night I was recording a podcast and I DMed one of the engineers on our team and told him about this tiny little iOS bug and he was like, why are you DMing me about this at nine o'clock at night? I think I was also supposed to be on vacation, I can't remember.

But then he got the bug fix the next day.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A specific example of how active dogfooding surfaces real issues and accelerates fixes through immediacy and shared urgency.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing dogfooding across the product team
quotes.text: So it's just things like don't try and record by yourself, find a friend. That's a much easier way to get into it or don't follow a script because then you're going to feel really awkward and uncomfortable and not feel good about it afterwards. Or don't just record a test thing for 30 seconds and publish it because you have to make yourself feel the pain that we're trying to understand in our users.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A practical “how to start” playbook that doubles as a dogfooding methodology: remove barriers, avoid false starts, and experience the full user journey.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing gut instinct with data
quotes.text: I think where people get into trouble is when they think that they can rely solely on the data.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A clear warning against over-indexing on quantitative signals when making product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing gut instinct with data
quotes.text: So thinking about, I guess a couple general things I would say are there are right and wrong times I think for both for your gut and for data. And then there are lots of different kinds of data and different ways to use that data.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A practical mental model: choose between intuition and data based on timing and the type of data available.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing gut instinct with data
quotes.text: So I think at Spotify there's obviously at places like Spotify, I mean, large organizations, there's obviously a lot more people that you need to coordinate.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Highlights the organizational constraint that changes how “gut” decisions must be communicated and justified at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing gut instinct with data
quotes.text: So I think I would think of your gut actually as a type of data and I think it's a totally valid one and it's just I think you need to be clear that that's what you're working with, but then it should be taken as seriously as any other data point.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Reframes intuition as an explicit input to decision-making, not an unspoken override of evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing gut instinct with data
quotes.text: And I think that in the times that either I have done this or I've seen other leaders do it, where they're just like, well, we're just going to do it this way even if you guys don't agree or if the data says something different, those projects are always immediately doomed from the beginning.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Actionable leadership lesson: unilateral gut calls without buy-in (or a compelling rationale) tend to fail.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 1.0 to 2.0: pivot despite good metrics
quotes.text: But I think we had this feeling, and when I say, I mean, mostly Mike and I at the time, Mike was our CEO, that it just wasn't ever going to be big enough.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A clear example of choosing mission-scale potential over strong retention and positive user feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 1.0 to 2.0: pivot despite good metrics
quotes.text: We wanted to make it something where anyone could easily tell their story, and we were like, if we keep digging ourselves into this niche that a small number of people really, really love, that's great, but that's not really the mission that we sent out set out to solve.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A mission-alignment test for deciding when a beloved product is pulling you into an unscalable niche.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 1.0 to 2.0: pivot despite good metrics
quotes.text: So I think that's one example of sometimes it's that whole users don't always know what to ask for, they don't always know what problems they need you to solve for them.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A reminder to look beyond explicit user requests and solve for underlying needs, especially during major product shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 1.0 to 2.0: pivot despite good metrics
quotes.text: I don't know. I guess the lesson is you have to be able to tell the signal through the noise, and even if you've got lots of vocal users asking for something, we used to have this rule, the 80/20 rule, where it's like you can't just build for that 20, I don't think we made this up by the way.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A practical prioritization heuristic: don’t let the loud minority dictate the roadmap when building for a broad market.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 1.0 to 2.0: pivot despite good metrics
quotes.text: I think you really have to be willing to kill your darlings and let things go when they're not getting where you need them to be.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A memorable principle for making hard calls to abandon successful features/products that block the long-term vision.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 2.0 to podcasting: embracing user demand
quotes.text: And when we decided, I think we started with like, oh, we'll do a little test and let people export us podcasts and see what happens.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A concrete example of using a small, low-commitment experiment to validate (or overturn) a strong product conviction.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 2.0 to podcasting: embracing user demand
quotes.text: And when we look back at our data, that's the moment when we saw the beginning of that hockey stick growth where it's like we had been growing, we had been doing well, and then you zoom out and you're like, okay, that was very clearly the thing we were missing.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Shows how a single feature (export/distribution) became the identifiable inflection point behind breakout growth.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 2.0 to podcasting: embracing user demand
quotes.text: And so I don't know what lesson to tell people to take away from that other than I think you have to just stay, especially in a startup mentality, you have to stay willing to be flexible and take in new information and new data points as your product matures and as your user base changes, there's going to be new things that you learn that are going to change how you think about it.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented operating principle: continuously update strategy as the product and users evolve.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 2.0 to podcasting: embracing user demand
quotes.text: And I think again, the one thing that was unwavering for us was our mission and everything else was mutable for us where we were like, whatever we need to do to get there will work.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A clear mental model for startups: keep mission fixed while treating tactics/positioning as flexible variables.

quotes.topic_title: Anchor 2.0 to podcasting: embracing user demand
quotes.text: Totally. And also, you never know which of those tiny product changes are going to end up being this existential moment for your business.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that seemingly small changes can become the defining lever—so keep shipping and watching closely.

quotes.topic_title: Unscalable distribution hack: interns submit to Apple
quotes.text: One of our principles from the very early days of Anchor was build things that don't scale, where we were like, we're a ridiculously tiny team. We're trying to do this really big thing.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A clear operating principle for early-stage teams: use unscalable tactics to achieve outsized outcomes before automation exists.

quotes.topic_title: Unscalable distribution hack: interns submit to Apple
quotes.text: We were obsessed with reducing friction, this was our constant battle.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A practical product strategy: prioritize systematically removing user friction as a core growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: Unscalable distribution hack: interns submit to Apple
quotes.text: we hired a couple of college interns and we brought them in and we were like, people are going to push this magical one button in the Anchor app and they're going to say, I want to distribute my podcast, and your job is going to be to do all that same manual stuff manually, but to them it's going to feel magical and it happened automatically.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A concrete “illusion of automation” playbook: deliver a magical UX first, even if the backend is manual.

quotes.topic_title: Unscalable distribution hack: interns submit to Apple
quotes.text: if we had said you request distribution and we'll have one of our team members get back to you in three days and let you know when you're on Apple Podcasts, that doesn't feel very magical or it's really saving you any time. If all you see as a user is you're hitting a button and then 24 hours later you're somehow magically on Apple Podcasts, that was so much easier than manual distribution was at the time.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Shows how packaging and perceived immediacy can be as important as the underlying work in driving adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Unscalable distribution hack: interns submit to Apple
quotes.text: we always talked about yes and when someone has an idea, how can you build on it and think about how it might work instead of saying, no, that can't work because,
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A team-level ideation method (“yes, and”) that encourages experimentation and avoids prematurely killing unconventional solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Census had a 10x increase in pipeline with a LinkedIn startup team for Webflow after ramping up on LinkedIn and Q4, they had the highest marketing source revenue quarter to date.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of LinkedIn Ads driving measurable B2B pipeline and revenue impact after ramping spend and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With LinkedIn ads you'll have direct access to and can build relationships with decision makers including 950 million members, 180 million senior execs and over 10 million C-level executives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical targeting advantage for B2B marketers: reach and relationship-building with decision-makers at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You'll be able to drive results with targeting and measurement tools built specifically for B2B.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable positioning: prioritize channels with B2B-native targeting and measurement to improve campaign effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In tech, LinkedIn generated two to 5x higher return on ad spend than any other social media platforms.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Strong comparative performance claim that can inform channel selection and budget allocation decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's one of the very rare success stories of an acquisition working out incredibly well. It was a small startup now powering two thirds of all new podcasts.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable acquisition outcome and scale data point that frames what “successful integration” can look like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Making the Spotify acquisition work
quotes.text: And so I think one of the big ways we were lucky is that what I've seen happen in a lot of acquisitions is you have an idea of what you're getting acquired for and you get excited and really attached to that vision, and then when that vision doesn't end up fitting into the company strategy, there's nowhere else to go.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A cautionary mental model for post-acquisition success: don’t over-anchor to the original acquisition thesis because strategy drift is common.

quotes.topic_title: Making the Spotify acquisition work
quotes.text: And I think we were really good at making sure that we stayed valuable to Spotify.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for acquired teams: optimize for ongoing value creation to the parent company, not just preserving the startup’s original plan.

quotes.topic_title: Making the Spotify acquisition work
quotes.text: When we came in, it was like we were very vocal about everything that we were doing, we did lots of internal marketing and made sure people were excited. We built a lot of really strong relationships. We made sure that every team at Spotify knew about us and what we were doing. We were constantly asking how we could help other teams.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A concrete integration playbook: internal marketing + relationship-building + proactive cross-team help to avoid getting “lost” post-acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Making the Spotify acquisition work
quotes.text: And when the strategy shifted, which it has dozens of times since we've gotten acquired almost five years ago, not like we just blindly followed, but we were always willing to get excited about whatever the next thing was and willing to be helpful and figure out how to make that work.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A pragmatic approach to constant strategy change: stay adaptable and supportive without being passive or uncritical.

quotes.topic_title: Making the Spotify acquisition work
quotes.text: But that goal hasn't really changed.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A useful distinction for navigating change: tactics and hypotheses can shift, but the mission should remain stable.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a startup pace inside Spotify
quotes.text: But the first thing that comes to mind, so when we were a startup, one of the first things we did when we were only a few people, we decided what our core values were going to be.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable practice: define core values early to preserve operating principles through growth and acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a startup pace inside Spotify
quotes.text: And when we got acquired, we had a conversation with our team where we said, we're going to of course embrace Spotify's culture and Spotify's core values, but we're not going to forget who we are as a team.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A concrete integration approach: explicitly commit to adopting the parent culture without losing the acquired team's identity.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a startup pace inside Spotify
quotes.text: We were shipping a new feature every two weeks, it was insane.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: A specific pace benchmark that makes “move fast” tangible and measurable for teams aiming to increase shipping cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a startup pace inside Spotify
quotes.text: But he said, I also want you to help me teach the rest of Spotify how to move more quickly, and I found that so motivating.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Counterintuitive acquisition lesson: the startup isn’t expected to slow down—it's tasked with exporting speed to the larger org.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a startup pace inside Spotify
quotes.text: I've continued to remind my team of even to this day where I think of that as part of my job here to help people think about how we can move quickly and what really matters.
quotes.speaker: Maya Prohovnik
quotes.context: Defines a leadership role in big companies: continually reinforce speed and prioritization amid growing complexity and stakeholders.
